Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Spintronics Without Spin Injection

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The continued scaling of CMOS technology is being driven by various approaches including spin-based electronics (or 'spintronics') due to potential gains in low-power operation, and by the prospect of realizing new forms of non-volatile, on-chip data storage. However, spintronic devices typically exhibit poor magnetoresistive values, except at cryogenic temperatures, and there are often practical issues regarding their manufacturability. Consequently, the full potential impact of spintronics on technology and society has remained unrealized. The ability to induce a high degree of spin polarization in epitaxially-formed graphene layers, deposited on complex oxides, is a major goal of this research; one that will allow the development of high performance, non-volatile, spin-based devices, capable of operating above room temperature. Social and economic benefits of such advances is huge, allowing not only the continuation of smaller, cheaper, and faster computing, but also making possible the development of massively-parallel, yet low-power and fault-tolerant, computer architectures. Graduate students will be trained in the interdisciplinary aspects of understanding fundamental relationships between surface/interface chemistry, charge and spin transport, and device physics. This mentoring also extends to the recruitment of undergraduate and high school students through existing, proven programs at the University of Buffalo, the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and at the University of North Texas.

In the interest of a new generation of post-CMOS nanoelectronics, technological challenges of spintronic devices include achieving high-fidelity spin-polarized carrier injection into a nonmagnetic semiconductor, and; realization of electrical schemes for the manipulation of magnetism while not compromising the possible energy gains offered by spintronics. This program provides a solution by realizing practical, graphene-based spintronic devices, based on industry-compatible graphene growth methods and operating at or above room temperature. These devices feature directly-grown, high-quality graphene on magnetic/multiferroic oxide substrates, and will exploit the spin polarization induced in the graphene channel through its interaction with the substrate, thereby obviating the need for efficient spin injection from ferromagnetic electrodes. The devices will furthermore be switched by means of the electric field applied across insulating oxides, thereby ensuring low-power operation. This project combines studies of the interfacial-chemistry of graphene/oxide hetero-junction formation, its effects on graphene spin polarization, and the development and testing of spin-field effect transistors. These devices are based on the direct growth of graphene/oxide heterojunctions, including Co3O4(111), Cr2O3(0001), and other ordered multiferroic oxides. The goal is to have a fundamental insight into how surface chemistry impacts spin transport, and also to yield manufacturable graphene-based spintronic devices, capable of exhibiting superior per-formance (MR>200%) in operation above room temperature.

Program Objectives

For nearly fifty years, the continued development of microelectronics has spurred the emergence of increasingly sophisticated consumer electronics, which has revolutionized our daily lives while promoting the economic preeminence of the nation. With almost every aspect of our daily lives touched by this technology, it is worth reflecting that the essential force for its development has been the capacity to integrate ever-increasing numbers of transistors onto a silicon chip. These transistors function as electrical switches, which, when connected into complex circuits, enable sophisticated calculations. We are usually unaware of this complexity, however, taking advantage instead of the capacity it offers to extract information from the internet, to capture a moment in a digital photograph, or to communicate across the globe. Nonetheless, the fact remains that these, and many other, benefits of modern technology have been made possible courtesy of a silent revolution. According to this, transistor sizes have continuously been shrunk to the nanoscale (to a few billionths of a millimeter), allowing billions of transistors to be accommodated on a single chip. This process of continued miniaturization is now approaching unavoidable roadblocks, in which critical problems arising from increased on-chip power consumption and fundamental limits to further miniaturization threaten our economic sustainability. Against this background, this project developed new materials and devices that are capable of revolutionizing transistor design. Innovative aspects of the research included making use of magnetism in a new class of materials (magnetic oxides), to manipulate physical information in a very different manner to that employed in conventional technology. This approach involves making use of the so-called “spin” of electrical charges, and switches this spin in a scheme that is capable of ultra-low-power implementation. By harnessing the special properties of ultrathin (essentially two-dimensional) materials such as graphene, these transistor schemes should allow permanent (non-volatile) data storage, for “instant-on” electronics and low-power operation at room temperature.

 

Intellectual Merit of the Work

This research involved a collaboration among scientists with expertise in materials synthesis (Kelber, Univ. of North Texas), surface spectroscopy and density-functional theory (Dowben, Univ. Nebraska Lincoln) and electronic materials and device characterization (Bird, Univ. at Buffalo). Collectively, these investigators worked to investigate methods for the preparation of novel materials, consisting of atomically-thin carbon (graphene), formed on various substrates. Theory was used to predict and explain the electrical properties of these materials, while these properties were explored in experiment using techniques of surface spectroscopy and electrical measurement. The understanding obtained from these studies will be essential to the development of practical, industrially-scalable, methods for the growth of graphene films for “spintronic” devices.

 

Broader Impact of the Work

This research supported the training of several PhD students, and undergraduates, all of whom received an education in forefront issues of materials science, surface physics, and nanoelectronics, all critical areas for the continued prosperity of the nation. This project furthermore supported the development of the next generation of scientists, through an outreach program that exposed 3rd-grade students to science and engineering by means of on-campus visits.
